fields.title: Locally produced material in goods
fields.description: The requirement that goods contain a high proportion of locally produced material.

fields.title: Restrictions on live animals, or animal and plant products
fields.description:
These sanitary and phytosanitary measures are implemented to protect human, animal, or plant health life. Threats to human, animal or plant health could arise from:

  • additives
  • contaminants
  • toxins
  • disease-causing organisms

fields.title: Environmental regulations on goods
fields.description: Restrictions on goods that could be harmful to the environment of the country the goods are being exported to.

fields.title: Safety regulations on goods
fields.description: Restrictions of imports of products from countries or regions where there is a lack of evidence of sufficient safety conditions.

fields.title: Quality measures on goods
fields.description:
Conditions of performance of goods, for example durability or hardness or quality of goods, for example content of defined ingredients.
These measures include:

  • product definitions
  • grading standards
  • production or processing regulations

fields.title: Packaging, labelling or design regulations
fields.description: Measures defining the information and packaging which should be provided to the consumer.

fields.title: Import quotas
fields.description: Limits on the amount of a good that can be imported into a country.

fields.title: Customs procedures
fields.description: Requirements that goods go through checks, or licences are secured before being imported.

fields.title: Rules of origin
fields.description: Issues related to countries requiring evidence which shows the country a good was made in.

fields.title: Restrictions on internal distribution
fields.description: Restrictions on internal distribution of a good being imported into a country. For example, in the US, transhipment can only be undertaken by US vessels, movement of some goods across or between states is subject to labour and union rules.

fields.title: Restrictions on foreign entry or movement of people
fields.description:
This includes:

  • visa costs
  • difficulties getting visas to do business
  • residence or nationality requirements
  • restrictions on buying land as foreign service supplier

fields.title: Local presence requirements
fields.description: Requirements for a service supplier to be a resident or from an enterprise in the country in which you are supplying a service.

fields.title: Fees that only apply to foreign service suppliers
fields.description: Policies that favour domestic service suppliers by placing unnecessary charges on foreign suppliers

fields.title: Restrictions on type of business, legal entity or joint venture that suppliers can operate under
fields.description: Requirements on businesses to have certain structures when operating in a country, or disadvantages to businesses with different structures.

fields.title: Limitations on access to key infrastructure
fields.description: For example, barriers to foreign service suppliers being able to open a local bank account or register websites with a local domain name

fields.title: Restrictions on foreign suppliers
fields.description:
Limits on the value or amount of services that can be supplied, the number of employees that suppliers can have, or the number of suppliers allowed in the market.

For example, this could be limits in the form of quotas or the requirement for businesses to fulfil certain conditions in order to obtain market access

fields.title: Qualification requirements
fields.description: Requirements for qualifications specific to the country you export to or qualifications not being recognised in the country you export to

fields.title: Specific taxes, other than tariffs, that are imposed to increase the price of goods.
fields.description: These might favour domestic firms over foreign competitors by being placed on imported products to make them more expensive than domestically produced alternative products.

fields.title: Government subsidies
fields.description: Transfers of public funds to specific companies, sectors or regions which artificially lower prices and distort competition. This could include preferential tax arrangements.

fields.title: Restrictions on how much money you can invest into a country
fields.description: Restrictions on the amount of money a supplier can invest in a country they are exporting to.

fields.title: Government procurement restrictions
fields.description: Regulations which encourage that a government buys goods or services from domestic suppliers. This can make it difficult for non-domestic suppliers to compete for a contract or for non-domestic goods and services to be used.

fields.title: Price controls
fields.description: Measures to control the price of imported goods. These can be used to support the price of domestic products when import prices are lower.

fields.title: Enforcement, or lack of enforcement, of rules and regulations
fields.description: A country that lacks any regulatory measures for products or services, or does not comply with international regulations like the WTO’s regulations.

fields.title: Unfair application of competition rules
fields.description: Competition law that is applied in an unfair way to target foreign firms or to protect domestic firms. This could include the failure to properly enforce competition law, or a lack of procedural rights for businesses to get a fair hearing.

fields.title: State-granted monopolies or exclusive rights
fields.description: A government granting one or more private companies the legal right to be the only operator in a market.

fields.title: State-owned enterprises
fields.description: Unfair advantages to state-owned companies, such as special rights or privileges, government funding, or exemptions from laws and regulations.

fields.title: Restrictions on local assets, local components or to train local workers
fields.description: Restrictions requiring you to use local assets, components or workers when operating in a country.

fields.title: Unfair application of intellectual property rights and regulations
fields.description:
This includes trade related intellectual property legislation and covers:

  • patents
  • trademarks
  • industrial designs
  • layout designs of integrated circuits
  • copyright
  • geographical indications
  • trade secrets

fields.title: Difficulties in accessing data
fields.description: Barriers to accessing data on regulations and procedures or points of contact.

fields.title: Restrictions on storing/sending data across countries
fields.description: Any barriers to the flow of data into countries in which you are supplying a service, as well as data localisation requirements or similar

fields.title: Testing, inspection and certification procedures
fields.description: Requirement to complete conformity assessments to show produce complies with technical regulations or standards

fields.title: Restrictions on business names
fields.description: Restrictions on the operation of service suppliers under the business name

fields.title: Tariffs or import duties
fields.description: Tariffs favour domestic firms over foreign competitors by increasing the price of goods. They can be resolved via unilateral reduction or multi/pluri-lateral agreements. Tariff schedules are available elsewhere, however specific tariffs that impact / are raised by UK businesses can be registered for business intelligence purposes.
